projectDesc.p: The Bank of America Digital Project, "Preserving American Freedom," explores how Americans have interpreted and fought for their freedoms from the 1600s to the present day and how these freedoms have shaped America's history. To this end, the project presents a selection of primary source documents from HSP's collection that illuminate conceptions, facets, and conflicts of freedom, as well as interpretive and contextual essays and resources for educators.

editorialDecl.p: This electronic file was created using manual keying following the recommendations for Level 4 of "Best Practices for TEI in Libraries" guidelines v3.0.

We have generally encoded entire documents/texts, not excerpts. We have encoded page breaks. We have also preserved original spelling, typographical errors, missing text, and original capitalization. For clippings from newspapers or other publications, we have transcribed just the text related to the article, ignoring other text or markings on the page that were purposefully or inadvertently included during clipping. We have regularized spacing between words and sentences to replace double (or triple) spaces to a single space.
We have not coded line breaks, end-of-line hyphenation, visual rendition of layout, font changes, or text alignment (left, right, center).

sp.speaker: ANNOUNCER
sp.p: During the following program we will offer you something you will prize for your home, den, or classroom. It is absolutely free. Listen, and have your pencil and paper handy.

sp.speaker: ANNOUNCER
sp.p: Lest We Forget Lest We Forget: Eternal Vigilance is the Price of Liberty. Today we present: Eternal Vigilance in Business.

sp.speaker: ANNOUNCER
sp.p: We are engaged in a total war. A total war must be fought by all people. And it is the people's war on the home front as well as on the battle front.World War II was commonly called a "people's war," referencing not only its inclusion of the entire state as a fighting force (overseas military was matched by war production on the home front), but also the wide range of support the war received. On the home front we cannot contribute our full strength to the war effort if we allow preconceived prejudices and artificial hiring standards to sabotage production. How can we expect to win a people's war if we maintain barriers against any group? For is not this great country dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal? One man or woman, or one group of men or women, cannot win this people's war. The people must win it, all together. An important meeting is taking place in the offices of one of our largest organizations engaged in the manufacture of the machinery of war.
The War Department is not satisfied with your production.
Mr. Johns, I assure you we're doing our level best.

Well, frankly, Mr. Peters, it isn't good enough. We had expected your tremendous industrial organization to make a great contribution to our war effort. The results so far have been definitely unsatisfactory. May I ask why?
The answer is simple: labor. We can't get the skilled machinists we need at Plant 32. And although Plant 32 is small in comparison to the rest of our factories, it is the keystone.
Hmm. Or the bottleneck. How can this bottleneck be eliminated?
I don't know. We've tried our best.
You wouldn't want us to pirate our labor, take men away from other factories?
Oh no, of course not. We'd only be hurting ourselves to pull a stunt like that.
We were almost desperate enough to try even that, but Mr. Kinley, our president, counseled against it.
By the way, where is Mr. Kinley? In my telegram, I stated definitely that I wanted to speak to him.
Well...uh...well, you see that...
Where is he?
He...well, frankly, we...we don't know!
You don't know?
You see, he left about three weeks ago, and we haven't heard from him.
Didn't he say where he was going?
No, he just left.
Well, I must say that this is highly irregular. I shall have to recommend that--

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Now look here, you can't go in there!
I'm afraid I must!
Good morning, gentlemen. I'm sorry if I'm late.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: I'm sorry, Mr. Peters, this man brushed past me.
It's quite all right, young lady. You may go now.

sp.speaker: SECRETARY
sp.p: Yes, sir.
Mr. Kinley, why are you...?
Dressed as a worker?
You men haven't forgotten that I started out in my business life as a worker?
Now that we've had our little masquerade, suppose you get down to business, Mr. Kinley. I've been waiting to see you for the last hour.
I'm sorry to have kept you waiting, Mr. Johns, but you see, this little masquerade, as you call it, has been doing a job.
You don't mean to say that you've actually been working in the plant yourself, Mr. Kinley?
You sound so shocked, Peters. Yes, I'm happy to say that I've discovered I'm still a pretty good machinist.
Surely you didn't intend to remedy the labor shortage by going to work in your own factory, Mr. Kinley?

Well, three weeks ago, I was almost ready to do that. But the main reason for this so-called disguise was to find out for myself just exactly what was wrong with 32. And gentlemen, I think I've gotten to the root of our trouble. I went to 32 and applied for a job. After standing in line for nearly three hours, I finally got in to see the personnel manager, George Rimmer. He didn't recognize me...
Ah yes...about your application, this name is Kinley. Any relation to Wilson Kinley, the president of our concern?
Do I have to be to get this job?
No, no, no. But even the initials are the same: W. A.
Er, William Ashton Kinley's the name.
Oh, I see.
Well, now to get at it. You say that you're a skilled machinist, but you haven't worked at your trade for the last twenty-five years. Why?
I've been in business for myself. When the war came along, I thought I'd do the thing I'm best fitted for to help the war effort.
The high wages wouldn't have anything to do with it, would they?
There is such a thing as patriotism, sir.
Hm? Ah, yes—yes, of course. Well, your application seems to be in order. When can you come to work?
Tomorrow morning, sir.
Good. Oh, by the way, you say your name is Kinley...
I don't only say it—it is Kinley.
I've no doubt that it is, but is it your adopted name, or were you born with it?
I don't understand.
Well, many men on arriving in this country from Europe or other places change their name under the—the impression that things will be easier for them with a more Anglicized name.
I don't really understand what you're trying to find out. Suppose I were foreign-born.
Well, during war times, er, we must check on the background of our employees—it's very important.
I see. Well, it happens that the name has been in my family for quite a long time. And I'm an American citizen.
Thank you. That's all. You will receive word at your lodging house when to report for work. Oh, just a moment, Kinley. Er, do you have any objections to working on Sundays?
No, not if it's necessary.
Well, some of our men prefer to take Sunday off because of their church.
Well, I consider myself a religious man, but if I can do something extra for my country by working Sundays...well, no objection.
Fine, fine. Er, then you may have Saturday or any other day that will make your Sabbath churchgoing convenient. Saturday all right?
My church doesn't hold services on Saturday.
Er, well, well, something probably can be arranged with some of the other men. Good day, Mr. Kinley—you'll hear from us not later than tomorrow.
Good day, Mr. Rimmer.
I left the personnel office of the factory and crossed the street to a little lunch room that catered to the factory workers. I sat down on one of the stools, and...

incident.desc: diner sounds: people talking, dishes clinking

sp.p: What'll it be, mister?
Scrambled eggs, toast, and coffee.
Okay, comin' up. Scrambled 2, burned 2, and ration 1!
What's good on the blue plate today, Gladys?
Hi, Mr. Janowsky. Spaghetti's good.
Always spaghetti. All right, give me the spaghetti.
All right. Tied in a knot on the blue!
Hello, Gregor. Still eating spaghetti, eh?
Eh? Ah yes, I always order it. Why, for goodness sake, Bill! Where you come from?
I wondered if you'd recognize me.
Oh, I recognize you, all right. Golly, I never forget my old pal. What are you do in work clothes? I thought you get big big-shot in plant, get rich!
Well, that's all over, Greg.
Oh, too bad. You lose all your money, eh? You lookin' for job in plant? After all, you still fine machinist.
I just got one, Greg.
Yeah? Ah, you lucky. I try for some time now, but I can't do it.
Why not? There's plenty of work, and you're a fine machinist.
Why not? Plenty "why nots." Plenty good men, but can't get job with that Rimmer.
I don't understand, Greg.
After lunch, you come with me. I show you some "why not."
Hello, Johnson. I want you to meet a good friend of mine, Bill Kinley.
How do you do, Mr. Kinley?
Hey, Johnson, tell Mr. Kinley about you not able to get job in plant.
Ain't much to tell. I been to school to learn machine tunin'. I got good marks. I graduated, but that man Rimmer won't hire me 'cause...'cause I ain't the same color he is.
But there's nothing in the application blank that asks race, religion, or color.
Nobody get in that plant 'til he gets an interview with Rimmer. He didn't even bother to talk to me—took one look at me and said no.
Hm. That explains the interview. Come on, Janowsky. I want to see more "why nots."

sp.speaker: UNNAMED JEWISH MAN
sp.p: Interview with Rimmer?

I never even got that far. He took one look at my name on the application and told me it wasn't the policy of the plant to hire Jews. Didn't find out if I was a good hand at my trade, just wanted to know what my religion was, that's all.
Are you satisfied, Bill? I have you meet five men, all good workers, but can't get job at plant.
Yeah, that's pretty bad. What about you, Greg? Why can't you get a job there?
Why? Because he no like my people, too. In first place, he thinks I am foreign. In second place, I am Catholic.
But you're an American citizen, Greg! He has no right to bar you.
Sure, I am American citizen—sure, I am American citizen! And my two boys in army, fighting in north Africa, they are good American citizens too. What I'm going to do about it?
I'll tell you what I'm going to do about it. You and I are going to see Rimmer in the personnel office together.

Mr. Rimmer, I know that you're shorthanded for men, so I brought back Gregor Janowsky. I used to work with Mr. Janowsky. In fact, he taught me most of what I know about machine tools. He needs a job. Now, you've got a job to give him.
Mr. Kinley, I have already interviewed Mr. Janowsky here, and unfortunately, he does not come up to our specifications.
But you haven't given him a chance! How can you tell?
Mr. Kinley, you will please confine your activities to the factory bench. I think I am the best judge of Mr. Janowsky's qualifications.

Just exactly what are the qualifications for employment here, Mr. Rimmer? I've discovered that you won't hire a Negro because of his color, or a Jew or a Catholic because of their religion. The men you've turned down are all good Americans, all expert workmen. Does a man have to be your color, go to your church, belong to your political party to work here? On whose authority do you make these restrictions?

Listen here, you Red agitator!To be a "red agitator" was to advocate communist or socialist tenets. Ethnic prejudice often led minorities and foreigners to be labeled as Communists. If you don't get out of this office immediately, I'll have you put out forcibly! I'll tell you whose authority counts around here! Mine! I do the hiring and firing!
Really.
I put your name down this morning as hired. But we don't want your kind around here! Now get out, and stay out!
That's all I wanted to know, Mr. Rimmer. It so happens there is one who can fire you. I say you're fired.
What?

I'm afraid that an American plant manufacturing the weapons for the people's war against Nazism and all the things it stands for is hardly the right place for you. I'll give you one hour to leave the plant. I happen to be your boss: W. A. Kinley.

And that, gentlemen, was our bottleneck: not the fact that we couldn't find good workmen, but that we had as our personnel manager Rimmer—a man who should have been working for NAME and company. I think that we shall no longer have trouble at Number 32, and I intend to go through the entire organization and root out every single instance of racial and religious prejudice. And I'm willing to wager that we shall have increased production as a direct result. The only way for Americans to fight a war is with American weapons, and we can't make American weapons with un-American intolerance. And now, gentlemen, I should like to introduce my new personnel manager, in complete charge of the personnel at all our plants.
Come in, Greg, and meet some of your fellow workers!

sp.speaker: ANNOUNCER
sp.p: Management must take the initiative, must open its doors to all loyal and capable workers. Individually, we may have our differences, but this one thing we have in common: our great love for our principles set down in our Constitution and written into our laws, that all men are created equal, and that they are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable rights. Among these are life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. And may we add another: the right to work. Lest We Forget: Eternal Vigilance in Business is the Price of Liberty.

sp.p: Would you like, absolutely free, a beautifully printed portfolio containing the portraits of NAME and NAME? Also reproductions of the flags of the United Nations in full color? A copy of the historic Atlantic Charter?The Atlantic Charter, drafted August 14, 1941, outlined the Allied goals of their involvement in World War II. And photographs of America's outstanding heroes of the Second World War? Each of these stirring subjects is suitable for framing for your home, den, or classroom. Just send a penny postcard with your name and address to Post Office Box 22, New York City, New York. You will receive this beautiful portfolio absolutely free by return mail. I repeat, Post Office Box 22, New York City, New York.
